description: ESL Placement Test question bank for Portuguese-speaking community college students (Metrology, Biotechnology, Cyber Security). Based on PLAN_FOR_PLACEMENT_EXAM_v1.2.md.

questions.rationale: Direct cognate. Anchor-easy question: virtually all test-takers should answer correctly. A student who misses Q1 is flagged for instructor follow-up (possible test anxiety, misunderstanding of instructions, or extremely low proficiency).

distractor_rationale.c: Verb form of the root (to import / importar), different part of speech
distractor_rationale.d: Similar prefix 'imp-' and suffix '-ante', but means 'impressive' (impressionante)

questions.rationale: High-frequency technical term, direct cognate. Relevant across all three programs (Metrology, Biotechnology, Cyber Security).

distractor_rationale.c: Similar prefix 'cons-', means 'to build' (construir)
distractor_rationale.d: Similar prefix 'cons-', means 'to consult' (consultar)

questions.rationale: Basic subject-verb agreement. 'Temperature' is singular, requires 'is'. Tests the most fundamental English grammar structure. The word 'temperature' is a cognate (temperatura), so the sentence context is accessible even to Tier 1 students.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Are' is plural form of 'to be' — common error for students who don't recognize singular/plural
distractor_rationale.c: 'Am' is first-person form — tests whether student knows 'am' is only for 'I'
distractor_rationale.d: 'Be' is the base/infinitive form — common error for students who know the verb but not conjugation

questions.rationale: 'Necessary' is a cognate (necessário). Context clue: water = essential for life. Tests ability to combine cognate recognition with basic sentence comprehension.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Impossible' (impossível) is a cognate but semantically wrong — water is not impossible for life
distractor_rationale.c: 'Dangerous' (perigoso) is semantically plausible if student misreads — water can be dangerous but is not 'dangerous for life' in this context
distractor_rationale.d: 'Expensive' (caro/dispendioso) is semantically unrelated but a common English adjective

questions.question_text:
A thermometer measures temperature. Temperature tells us if something is hot or cold.

What does a thermometer measure?
questions.rationale: Direct literal comprehension. Answer is explicitly stated in the first sentence. Both 'thermometer' (termômetro) and 'temperature' (temperatura) are cognates, making the passage accessible. Tests whether the student can extract a specific fact from a 2-sentence passage.

distractor_rationale.b: 'Weight' (peso) — plausible measurement concept but not mentioned in passage
distractor_rationale.c: 'Time' (tempo) — plausible measurement concept; 'tempo' in Portuguese means both 'time' and 'weather', adding confusion
distractor_rationale.d: 'Distance' (distância) — plausible measurement concept but not mentioned

questions.rationale: One of the most common English adjectives. No cognate, but very basic — most students have encountered 'big' through media exposure. Tests pure vocabulary knowledge without cognate scaffolding.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Pequeno' means 'small' — the antonym, a classic trap for students who confuse the two
distractor_rationale.c: 'Médio' means 'medium' — related to size but not the correct meaning
distractor_rationale.d: 'Vazio' means 'empty' — unrelated but a common Portuguese adjective

questions.rationale: Verb-object collocation. 'Drink water' is a basic phrase. All options are base form (first person singular), so the question tests vocabulary (which verb collocates with 'water'), not grammar. v1.1 fix: changed from third-person forms (eats/drinks/sleeps/reads) to base forms (eat/drink/sleep/read) to match first-person subject 'I'.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Eat' — semantically related to consumption but wrong collocation (you eat food, not water)
distractor_rationale.c: 'Sleep' — common daily activity verb but completely unrelated to water
distractor_rationale.d: 'Read' — common daily activity verb but completely unrelated to water

questions.question_text:
The sun gives light and energy to the Earth. Plants use sunlight to make food and grow.

What do plants use to grow?
questions.rationale: Literal comprehension. Answer is explicit in the second sentence. v1.1 fix: improved distractors from implausible ('Darkness', 'Cold air') to nature-related alternatives that a student who didn't understand the passage might plausibly select.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Water and soil' — scientifically true (plants do need these) but not what the passage says, testing whether student reads vs. guesses from world knowledge
distractor_rationale.c: 'Wind' — nature-related, plausible guess for a student who recognized the outdoor/nature topic but couldn't parse the sentence
distractor_rationale.d: 'Moonlight' — structurally similar to 'Sunlight' (compound noun with '-light'), testing precise reading

questions.rationale: Direct cognate. All distractors are also Portuguese cognates starting with 'pro-', testing precise recognition rather than just 'does this look like Portuguese?'.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Programa' means 'program' — same prefix 'pro-', similar ending pattern, common false match
distractor_rationale.c: 'Processo' means 'process' — same prefix 'pro-', similar ending '-o', could confuse students relying on first syllable
distractor_rationale.d: 'Projeto' means 'project' — same prefix 'pro-', similar ending '-o', another plausible false match

questions.rationale: Third-person singular present simple requires the '-es' suffix. 'The computer' is a singular subject. Tests whether the student recognizes the subject-verb agreement pattern. Sits at the upper boundary of Band 1, transitioning toward Band 2 difficulty.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Process' (base form) — most common error; student knows the verb but doesn't apply third-person -es
distractor_rationale.c: 'Processed' (past simple) — wrong tense; no past time marker in the sentence
distractor_rationale.d: 'Processing' (present participle) — wrong form; would need auxiliary 'is' to be correct ('is processing')

questions.question_text: What is the best definition of "achieve"?
questions.rationale: Common academic verb, not a cognate. Tests understanding of English definitions (options are in English, not Portuguese). Marks the shift from Band 1 (Portuguese translations) to Band 2 (English definitions).

distractor_rationale.a: 'To receive something' — phonetically similar ending ('-eive' vs. '-ieve'), plausible confusion with 'receive'
distractor_rationale.c: 'To believe in something' — phonetically similar ('-ieve' ending), very common confusion for ESL learners
distractor_rationale.d: 'To teach someone' — phonetically similar ('teach' vs. 'ach-ieve'), plausible if student only recognizes partial sounds

questions.rationale: Past tense marker 'last week' requires past simple form. Tests whether the student can use temporal adverbs to select the correct tense — a key Tier 2 skill.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Completes' (present simple) — ignores the past time marker 'last week'
distractor_rationale.c: 'Completing' (present participle) — wrong form; would need auxiliary 'was' to be correct
distractor_rationale.d: 'Will complete' (future) — contradicts the past time marker 'last week'

questions.question_text:
Bacteria are tiny living organisms. Some bacteria are helpful and live in our bodies. Other bacteria can cause infections and make us sick.

According to the passage, what is true about bacteria?

options.text: Some bacteria are helpful, and some are harmful
Bacteria do not live in the human body

questions.rationale: Requires synthesizing information from sentences 2 and 3. Tests the 'some...other' structure and the ability to avoid overgeneralization ('all bacteria are...'). Biotechnology-relevant topic.

distractor_rationale.a: 'All bacteria are dangerous' — overgeneralization from sentence 3 only; ignores sentence 2
distractor_rationale.b: 'All bacteria are helpful' — overgeneralization from sentence 2 only; ignores sentence 3
distractor_rationale.d: 'Bacteria do not live in the human body' — directly contradicts sentence 2 ('live in our bodies')

options.text: She go to the laboratory yesterday.
She goes to the laboratory yesterday.
She went to the laboratory yesterday.
She going to the laboratory yesterday.

questions.rationale: Tests past simple vs. present simple with time marker 'yesterday'. Each distractor represents a specific common error pattern among Portuguese-speaking ESL learners.

distractor_rationale.a: 'She go' — base form without conjugation; common for students who haven't learned any tense markers
distractor_rationale.b: 'She goes' — present simple third-person; student knows conjugation but ignores 'yesterday'
distractor_rationale.d: 'She going' — present participle without auxiliary; common reduction error

questions.rationale: Comparative form with 'than'. Tests knowledge of comparative adjective formation for short adjectives (-er, not 'more'). Metrology-relevant content (material properties).

distractor_rationale.a: 'Strong' (base form) — ignores the comparative structure signaled by 'than'
distractor_rationale.c: 'Strongest' (superlative) — wrong degree; superlative is used for 3+ items, not comparison of two
distractor_rationale.d: 'More strong' — applies the 'more + adjective' pattern incorrectly; this pattern is for longer adjectives, not one-syllable ones like 'strong'

questions.question_text:
Cybersecurity protects computer systems from attacks. Hackers try to steal information or damage systems. Companies use firewalls and passwords to prevent attacks. Good cybersecurity is essential for businesses today.

How do companies protect their systems?
questions.rationale: Answer is explicit in sentence 3. Requires identifying relevant information from a 4-sentence passage. Cybersecurity-relevant topic. Multiple cognates ('cybersecurity', 'systems', 'information', 'firewalls') make the passage partially accessible.

distractor_rationale.a: 'By hiring hackers' — confuses the attacker (hackers) with the defense; plausible if student only skims
distractor_rationale.c: 'By avoiding the internet' — a real-world misconception but not stated in the passage
distractor_rationale.d: 'By stealing information' — attributes the hacker's action to the companies; tests careful reading

questions.rationale: Key technical term for Metrology students. Partial cognate (acurado/preciso in Portuguese). Tests vocabulary at the academic/technical level that distinguishes Tier 2 from Tier 1.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Fast and efficient' — plausible attribute of a good system but not the meaning of 'accurate'
distractor_rationale.c: 'Large and important' — unrelated adjective pair; tests whether student is guessing
distractor_rationale.d: 'Difficult and complex' — plausible confusion with 'intricate' or 'elaborate'

questions.question_text: Scientists _____ a new vaccine that is now saving lives.
questions.rationale: Present perfect is required because the action (discovering) has a result relevant to the present ('is now saving lives'). The temporal context 'that is now saving lives' makes past simple ('discovered') incorrect — past simple would require a completed-in-the-past context. Distinguishes Tier 2 from Tier 1. v1.1 fix: added 'that is now saving lives' to disambiguate; original 'Scientists _____ a new vaccine' was ambiguous between past simple and present perfect.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Discovered' (past simple) — would be correct without the present-relevance clause; the strongest distractor
distractor_rationale.c: 'Are discovering' (present continuous) — implies the discovery is ongoing, contradicting 'is now saving lives' (already discovered)
distractor_rationale.d: 'Will discover' (future) — contradicts the present-relevance clause ('is now saving lives' means it's already happened)

questions.question_text:
Renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, produce electricity without burning fossil fuels. Unlike coal and natural gas, they do not release greenhouse gases during operation. However, their energy output depends on weather conditions, which can be unpredictable.

What is a disadvantage of renewable energy mentioned in the passage?

options.text: It is more expensive than fossil fuels
Its output depends on unpredictable weather

questions.rationale: Entry-level Band 3 question with a shorter passage (3 sentences) to create a gradual transition from Band 2. Tests the ability to identify a specific disadvantage from a passage that discusses both advantages and disadvantages. Requires understanding the contrast signaled by 'However.' v1.1 change: replaced original 5-sentence climate change passage for gradual Band 2-to-3 transition.

distractor_rationale.a: 'It produces greenhouse gases' — directly contradicts sentence 2 ('do not release greenhouse gases'); tests whether student reads carefully vs. associates 'energy' with 'pollution'
distractor_rationale.b: 'It is more expensive than fossil fuels' — a real-world argument but not mentioned in the passage; tests 'is it in the text?'
distractor_rationale.d: 'It requires burning coal' — directly contradicts sentence 1 ('without burning fossil fuels')

questions.question_text: Which sentence uses the passive voice correctly?

options.text: The experiment conducts by the students.
The experiment was conducted by the students.
The experiment is conducting by the students.

questions.rationale: Tests understanding of passive construction (be + past participle). Option (d) is grammatically correct but is active voice, not passive — a strong distractor for students who confuse the two voices.

distractor_rationale.a: 'Conducts by' — uses present simple active form instead of passive; missing auxiliary 'be'
distractor_rationale.c: 'Is conducting by' — uses present continuous active instead of passive; '-ing' form is not past participle
distractor_rationale.d: 'The students conducted the experiment' — grammatically correct active voice; tests whether student knows the difference between active and passive

questions.question_text: If the temperature _____ too high, the equipment will malfunction.
questions.rationale: First conditional (If + present simple, will + base verb). Tests knowledge of conditional structures, which are a Tier 3 skill. Metrology-relevant context (temperature, equipment).

distractor_rationale.a: 'Rise' (base form) — common error: omitting the third-person '-s' in the if-clause
distractor_rationale.c: 'Rose' (past simple) — would create a second conditional meaning ('If the temperature rose... the equipment would malfunction'); wrong conditional type
distractor_rationale.d: 'Risen' (past participle) — wrong form; would need auxiliary 'has' ('has risen') or be part of a different construction

questions.question_text:
Biotechnology involves using living organisms or their components to develop useful products. One application is the production of insulin for diabetes treatment. Historically, insulin was extracted from animal pancreases. However, modern biotechnology allows scientists to genetically engineer bacteria to produce human insulin. This method is safer, more efficient, and more cost-effective.

Why is genetically engineered insulin better than animal-derived insulin?

options.text: It is safer, more efficient, and cheaper

questions.rationale: Answer is in the final sentence. Requires understanding 'safer, more efficient, more cost-effective' = better. Biotechnology-relevant topic with a 5-sentence passage.

distractor_rationale.a: 'It is extracted from animals' — describes the OLD method (sentence 3), not the new one; tests whether student confuses the two methods
distractor_rationale.c: 'It requires human pancreases' — fabricated detail; neither method uses human pancreases (animal pancreases were used historically)
distractor_rationale.d: 'It is a historical method' — describes the OLD method ('Historically, insulin was extracted...'); the new method is modern

options.text: The scientist who discovered the cure was awarded a prize.
The scientist discovered the cure was awarded a prize.
The scientist, discovered the cure, was awarded a prize.
The scientist which discovered the cure was awarded a prize.

questions.rationale: Tests understanding of relative clauses ('who' for people). Requires knowing that 'which' is for things, not people. Option (b) is ambiguous without the relative pronoun (could be misread as two separate clauses).

distractor_rationale.a: 'The scientist discovered the cure was awarded a prize' — missing relative pronoun; creates a garden-path sentence that is confusing or ungrammatical
distractor_rationale.c: 'The scientist, discovered the cure, was awarded a prize' — incorrect comma usage; commas don't replace relative pronouns
distractor_rationale.d: 'The scientist which discovered the cure...' — uses 'which' for a person; 'which' is for things/objects, 'who' is for people

questions.question_text:
Climate change refers to long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns. While natural processes can cause these shifts, human activities have been the main driver since the 1800s. Burning fossil fuels generates greenhouse gas emissions that trap heat in the atmosphere. As a result, global temperatures have risen approximately 1.1°C since pre-industrial times. Scientists warn that further warming could have severe consequences for ecosystems and human societies.

What can be inferred from the passage?

options.text: Human activities are the primary cause of recent climate change
Global temperatures have decreased since the 1800s
Scientists believe climate change will have no impact

questions.rationale: Requires synthesizing information from sentences 2 and 3. Inferential, not just literal — the passage says humans are the 'main driver', and the student must infer this means 'primary cause'. v1.1 change: moved from Q19 to Q24 position (5-sentence passage is appropriate for upper Band 3).

distractor_rationale.a: 'Climate change is entirely natural' — contradicted by sentence 2 ('human activities have been the main driver'); tests whether student notes the word 'While' (concessive)
distractor_rationale.c: 'Global temperatures have decreased' — directly contradicts sentence 4 ('have risen approximately 1.1°C')
distractor_rationale.d: 'Scientists believe climate change will have no impact' — contradicts sentence 5 ('severe consequences')

questions.question_text:
Precision and accuracy are two distinct concepts in measurement. Precision refers to how close repeated measurements are to each other. Accuracy refers to how close a measurement is to the true value. A measurement can be precise but not accurate if the instrument has a systematic error. For example, a scale that consistently reads 2 kg too high is precise (consistent) but inaccurate (wrong).

According to the passage, what is the difference between precision and accuracy?

options.text: There is no difference; they mean the same thing
Precision is about consistency; accuracy is about correctness
Precision is about correctness; accuracy is about consistency

questions.rationale: Anchor-hard question. Requires understanding technical definitions and distinguishing two related concepts. Critical for Metrology students. Option (c) is a strong distractor because it reverses the two definitions — only a careful reader will distinguish it from the correct answer. A student who answers Q25 correctly almost certainly belongs in Tier 3.

distractor_rationale.a: 'There is no difference' — directly contradicts sentence 1 ('two distinct concepts'); only selected by someone who didn't read the passage
distractor_rationale.c: 'Precision is about correctness; accuracy is about consistency' — reverses the definitions; the strongest distractor, catches students who understood the concepts are different but mixed up which is which
distractor_rationale.d: 'Only accuracy matters in measurement' — not stated in the passage; the passage discusses both concepts as important
